abstract.shortdesc: This documentation details the support provides for the integration of 3rd-party components with a platform deployment, whether that is a completely separate service or a plugin/driver to an existing service in the stack. The 3rd-party mechanism supports the integration of a range of different types of content..

body.p:
provides great flexibility when deploying your cloud, including:
The ability to subset the services or service components to be deployed.
Control of the distribution of services across the control plane and the rest of the cloud.
Network topology definition.
Disk layout specification.
Customization using configuration files.
extends this flexibility by supporting the integration of 3rd-party components with a platform deployment, whether that is a completely separate service or a plugin/driver to an existing service in the stack. The 3rd-party mechanism supports the integration of a range of different types of content:

ol.li: Packages: Addition of 3rd-party packages not available in repos onto a separate repo on the Helion lifecycle mananger node, e.g. Debian packages or RHEL rpms. After import, these packages are automatically available for installation on any target cloud node.

Python venv content: services are deployed as separate python virtual environments (venvs). The third-party mechanism supports the import of 3rd-party python code for two use cases:
The patching of an existing venv, e.g. adding a plugin to the neutron venv.
Creation of a new venv, where this venv can optionally be derived from an existing venv.

Service Definitions: services and service components are defined in a series of yaml files, which describe various aspects of a service, such as endpoints (VIP and otherwise), relationships with other services (e.g. requires rabbitmq) and whether creds need to be allocated . This data is ultimately used to generate Ansible variables for consumption by the playbooks. The 3rd-party mechanism allows for the definition of new services or service components, where relationships between each other and with -supplied services can be defined. These service definitions will be processed along with the set of service definitions to produce Ansible vars, which can be utilised by imported 3rd-party Ansible playbooks.

Ansible: Addition of 3rd-party playbook and roles for the deployment and configuration of 3rd-party components. These playbooks can be integrated with all of the standard Helion lifecycle manager lifecycle operations, such as deployment, upgrade and reconfiguration.

li.ph: A third-party service integration may require additional content to be deployed to a node, where that content is not packaged as a deb/rpm, or the content is not a python plugin to be patched in an existing service venv or python code for a new venv. Helion lifecycle manager provides a generic mechanism for packaging such content and delivering it to target nodes (coupled with the use of Helion lifecycle manager Ansible modules in the 3rd-party Ansible playbooks). For example, this mechanism can be used to deliver a Java-based application to target cloud nodes.

ol.li: Centralized Logging profiles: Third-party services log files can be added to the centralised logging service provided by . This service also manages the logrorate policy for services that register with it. To configure your third-party service with centralised logging, a logging profile must be added.

service configuration: Some services (currently, just Neutron) provide an interface for injecting 3rd-party customisations of the deployment of that service, which includes the addition of configuration data to certain selected configuration files.

body.p: The import of any combination of the above content types can be used in support of a particular 3rd-party integration. The remainder of this document details the main steps for using the import mechanism and how each of the content types is prepared in advance of running the import.

The Helion lifecycle manager 3rd-party import mechanism allows the import of various types of content into the platform in advance of a deployment. In the general use case, the 3rd-party content is imported after the lifecycle manager has been initialised (i.e. after hos-init.bash has been executed). The general procedure for importing 3rd-party content is as follows:

ol.li: Ensure that the lifecycle manager has been initialised: ~/hos-4.0.0/hos-init.bash

Prepare 3rd-party content for import on the deployer.
Create a top-level directory on the lifecycle manager under ~/third-party and create sub-directories under that, according to the different third-party content being imported, e.g.: third-party/ └── myservice ├── ansible ├── logging ├── other ├── pkgs ├── services └── venvs
Populate each sub-directory with your 3rd-party content; details on the layout for each content type are detailed below.Note that the third-party area can also be populated with extensions content shipped with , e.g. for a -DCN deployment: cp -r ~/helion/hos_extensions/dcn ~/third-party/ Note: Additional content (outside of that provided with extensions) must be added to the third-party area for a -DCN deployment.

Run the 3rd-party import playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost third-party-import.yml
Note that RHEL artefacts (rpms or any updates against RHEL venvs – provides a different set of service venvs for hlinux and RHEL) are not imported by default. If this is required, run the third-party-import playbook as follows: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost third-party-import.yml -e third_party_rhel_enabled

Proceed with the cloud deployment as per normal:
Prepare configuration input files to describe your target cloud (which may include references to imported 3rd-party services) and commit those changes via git.
Provision your baremetal nodes.
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml -e encrypt="" -e rekey=""
Ready the deployment: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Deploy your cloud (which now includes 3rd-party components): cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml

body.p: The following sections provide details on how to supply the different types of third-party content for import. The following assumes that you have created a top-level directory (named according to your particular 3rd-party integration) under the third-party area on the deployer, e.g. as follows:
Further sub-directories are created under the directory specific to a third-party integration, e.g. third-party/myservice, according to different types of content required.
The third-party import mechanism supports the import of both Debian packages and RHEL packages, as shown in the diagram below:
To prepare third-party packages for import, the following steps are required:

ol.li: Populate the debian sub-directory with the full set of debian packages required for the third-party service, including any dependencies.
Populate the rhel sub-directory with the full set of RHEL packages required for the third-party service, including any dependencies.

body.p: A sample layout of third-party packages ready for import is shown below:
body.codeblock: third-party/myservice/pkgs ├── debian │ ├── pkg1.deb │ └── pkg2.deb └── rhel ├── pkg1.rpm └── pkg2.rpm
body.p: The third-party-import playbook will scan for packages under all directories matching the pattern ~/third/*/pkgs/debian or ~/third/*/pkgs/rhel and populate the 3rd-party apt repo (separate to the base apt repo) with deb packages and populate the 3rd-party yum repo (separate to the yum repo, if present) with rpm packages. The third-party apt and yum repo packages will then be available for installation in subsequent deployments of cloud nodes, typically carried out by imported 3rd-party Ansible playbooks.
The third-party import mechanism supports both the patching of existing venvs and the creation of new venvs. An example of the patching of an existing neutron venv is illustrated below:
To prepare content for the update or creation of a new venv, the following steps are required:

ol.li: Create an appropriately-named sub-directory under the venvs directory for each separate set of python content to be imported, e.g. pluginA or serviceA in the example below.

For each of these sub-directories:
Populate one or all of the debs, src or whls directories with the source content.
Populate the pip-deps directory with any pip requirements, arising from the above.
Create services.yml

body.p: A sample directory layout for the patching of an existing venv with plugin code and for the creation of a new venv is as follows:
body.codeblock: third-party/myservice/venvs ├── pluginA │ ├── debs │ ├── pip-deps │ ├── services.yml │ ├── src │ └── whls └── serviceA ├── debs ├── pip-deps ├── services.yml ├── src └── whls
body.p: For both cases, the content provided can be in three forms, each placed in specifically named sub-directories:

ul.li: debs: A set ot Debian packages containing python code, which will be extracted, converted into a wheel and installed into the destination venv.
src: A set of source tarballs, which are installed directly into the destination venv.
whls: A set of wheels, which are installed directly into the destination venv.

body.p: Python wheels are the preferred format for this content as they lower install time and have no install-time dependencies.
For the above installations, additional pip dependencies may be required. The third-party import mechanism will scan the pip-deps sub-directory to satisfy such requirements.
The nature of the destination venv referred to above depends on the services.yml file, which must be present. To patch an existing venv, such as neutron, the services.yml is defined as follows:

The result of this is to create a new Neutron venv, updated with content from the debs, src or whls (and pip-deps) directories. After the third-party import has been completed, subsequent calls to install the Neutron venv will install this updated venv rather than the original venv supplied with .
An example services.yml for the creation of a new venv is as follows:

In this case a new venv is created called "myserviceA", which is based off an existing nova-client venv. This additionally has content installed into it from the debs, src or whls directories. After the third-party import has been completed, this new venv is available for installation. Additional third-party playbooks will be required to install this venv.

To deploy a cloud with Helion lifecycle manager, the cloud operator must prepare an input model that describes the cloud configuration in terms of which services (OpenStack and supporting) run on which server nodes, how sets of server nodes are configured in terms of network configuration and disk layout, the overall network layout and much more (an overview of the input model can be found here). The input model refers to a service, where a service is defined a collection of service-components that provide a particular feature; for example nova provides the compute service and consists of the following service-components: nova-api, nova-scheduler, nova-conductor, nova-novncproxy, and nova-compute.

A service may comprise of just one service-component, such as rabbitmq or mysql. A service-component represents the smallest unit of deployment for Helion lifecycle manager. A cloud operator describes the desired cloud deployment in terms of the selection layout of service components across groups, known as clusters . A service and its constituent service components are typically defined in separate yaml files (Note: the convention is to use separate files for general readability and organisation, but this is not strictly required); the full set of services and service components can be viewed on the lifecycle manager under the ~/helion/hos/services directory. For example, the list of yaml files defining the nova service and its constituent service-components (in ) is as follows:
body.codeblock: ~/helion/hos/services$ ls -l nova total 60 -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 3301 Jul 13 07:41 api.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 1516 Jul 13 07:41 compute.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 767 Jul 13 07:41 conductor.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 716 Jul 13 07:41 console_auth.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 777 Jul 13 07:41 esx_compute_proxy.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 764 Jul 13 07:41 ironic_compute_proxy.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 809 Jul 13 07:41 ironic_compute.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 778 Jul 13 07:41 ironic_scheduler.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 1342 Jul 13 07:41 kvm_compute.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 769 Jul 13 07:41 new_esx_compute_proxy.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 1197 Jul 13 07:41 nova-client.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 813 Jul 13 07:41 nova-metadata.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 2907 Jul 13 07:41 nova.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 1002 Jul 13 07:41 novncproxy.yml -rw-r--r-- 1 stack stack 767 Jul 13 07:41 scheduler.yml
body.p: The third-party import mechanism supports the import of third-party defined services and service components, as shown in the following diagram:
To set up third-party services for import, place the set of yaml files under the services sub-directory, e.g.:
body.codeblock: third-party/myservice/services └── serviceA ├── serviceA-client.yml ├── serviceA-plugin.yml ├── serviceA-server.yml └── serviceA.yml
body.p: When the third-party-import playbook has completed, the above third-party service definitions will have been added to the existing set of services under ~/helion/hos/services and committed to git (on the site branch). Here is a sample git log entry for the addition of a set of third-party service definitions:
body.codeblock: commit 21103bd725e3613b341d06dee9d3eed6ce0aafc7 Author: Helion git user <helion@hpe.com> Date: Wed Jul 13 09:46:19 2016 +0000 Third-party services import
body.p: For details on the creation of the service definitions files, please refer to the separate guide on the "Implementing a new service in Helion lifecycle manager"
Helion lifecycle manager supports the import of third-party Ansible playbooks roles, as illustrated in the following diagram:
To prepare third-party Ansible content for import, carry out the following steps:

ol.li: Implement the set of playbooks and roles, as per the guide: "Implementing a new service in Helion lifecycle manager"

li.ph: Add hooks for the integration third-party playbooks with Helion lifecycle manager lifecycle operations.
Create a symlinks yaml file to indicate which configuration files will be exposed for customer edit in the my_cloud/config area.
Copy the full set of playbooks, roles, hooks and config dir to the ansible sub-directory for this particular integration.

p.ph: A sample layout of Ansible content ready for import is as follows:

body.codeblock: . ├── config │ └── myservice-symlinks.yml ├── hooks.d │ └── myservice │ ├── post-nova-deploy.yml │ ├── post-nova-reconfigure.yml │ ├── post-nova-stop.yml │ └── pre-monasca-agent-deploy.yml ├── myservice-deploy.yml ├── myservice-reconfigure.yml ├── myservice-start.yml ├── myservice-stop.yml └── roles ├── myservice-client │ ├── defaults │ │ └── main.yml │ └── tasks │ ├── configure.yml │ ├── install.yml │ ├── start.yml │ └── stop.yml ├── myservice-plugin │ ├── defaults │ │ └── main.yml │ └── tasks │ ├── configure.yml │ ├── install.yml │ ├── start.yml │ └── stop.yml └── myservice-server ├── defaults │ └── main.yml ├── tasks │ ├── configure.yml │ ├── install.yml │ ├── start.yml │ └── stop.yml └── templates └── server.conf.j2
body.p: When the third-party-import playbook has completed, the above set of playbooks, roles and hooks are added to ~/helion/hos/ansible on the lifecycle manager and committed to git (on the site branch). Here is a sample git log entry representing the import of some third-party Ansible content:
body.codeblock: commit 9ca9b47f6d2840b48624ffa94fb6b8a072466811 Author: Helion git user <helion@hpe.com> Date: Wed Jul 13 09:46:21 2016 +0000 Third-party Ansible import
body.p: For details on the implementation of ansible playbooks and roles for Helion lifecycle manager, please refer to the separate guide on the "Implementing a new service in Helion lifecycle manager".

In addition to adding the set of third-party Ansible playbooks and roles, the third-party top-level playbooks must be integrated with top-level Helion lifecycle manager playbooks for all supported lifecycle operations, such as deploy, upgrade and so on. The next section details how that is achieved. The final section on Ansible details how to set up symlinks for third-party configuration templates.

topic.title: Helion lifecycle manager Ansible Hook Mechanism

body.p: To fully integrate your third-party playbooks, you must use the Helion lifecycle manager mechanism for hooking third-party playbooks into the major Helion lifecycle manager lifecycle operations so that, for example, when a deployment is run, it includes your playbooks for deploying a third-party service. Helion lifecycle manager supports the integration of third-party level playbooks with the following Helion lifecycle manager lifecycle operations:

To hook into Helion lifecycle manager lifecycle operations, you must define a set of hook playbooks under the hooks.d directory within your Ansible content, where those playbooks follow a specific naming convention:
where:

ul.li: custom: Any named directory under hooks.d for the placement of hook playbooks. Any duplicate hooks targeting the same action or service-action combination will be alphabetically sorted according to this name to determine the ultimate ordering.
action: Refers to the top-level operation that Helion lifecycle manager is executing, e.g. deploy or reconfigure.
service: Refers to the name of a service as per its naming in the Helion lifecycle manager top-level playbooks (hlm-deploy.yml, hlm-reconfigure.yml, etc.), e.g nova, glance, swift, etc.

body.note: To integrate into hlm-status.yml, your hook needs to be called post-status.yml.
body.p: The set of hooks in the above sample Ansible content layout are:
body.codeblock: . ├── hooks.d │ └── myservice │ ├── post-nova-deploy.yml │ ├── post-nova-reconfigure.yml │ ├── post-nova-stop.yml │ └── post-nova-start.yml
body.p: Based on the above, the post-nova-deploy.yml playbook will be invoked as part of a site.yml execution and is guaranteed to run after the nova-deploy.yml part of the overall run. Similarly, a run of hlm-reconfigure.yml will execute post-nova-reconfigure.yml after nova-reconfigure.yml.

When the third-party-import playbook has completed, the full contents of the Ansible directory will be merged with the existing ~/helion/hos/ansible area on the lifecycle manager. The Ansible hooks are not processed until the ready-deployment playbook has been run, after which the inclusion of the hooks will be apparent in the Helion lifecycle manager playbooks in the scratch area, i.e. under /scratch/ansible/next/helion/hos. For example, from the above hooks specification, hlm-deploy.yml is rendered as follows:
body.codeblock: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # Top-level HLM deploy playbook # # Automatically managed by Ansible and will be overwritten on each # deploy ready. --- # Regather facts on all hosts in case of configuration changes that haven't # been reflected in the fact cache - include: hlm-refresh-facts.yml - include: sosreport-deploy.yml - include: upgrade-bootstrap.yml # pre deploy Third party hooks # deploy services and Third party hooks # HLM-1259: when disabling the monasca part of the deployment, # edit ~/.ansible.cfg and change the [default] / library setting # as outlined in that file. - include: monasca-agent-deploy.yml - include: tls-deploy.yml - include: clients-deploy.yml - include: percona-deploy.yml - include: rabbitmq-deploy.yml - include: FND-CLU-deploy.yml - include: FND-AP2-deploy.yml - include: memcached-deploy.yml - include: keystone-deploy.yml - include: barbican-deploy.yml - include: zookeeper-deploy.yml - include: monasca-deploy.yml - include: hlm-ux-services-deploy.yml # ops console depends on kafka, installed by monasca - include: ops-console-deploy.yml - include: spark-deploy.yml - include: monasca-transform-deploy.yml - include: swift-deploy.yml - include: glance-deploy.yml - include: neutron-deploy.yml - include: ironic-deploy.yml - include: vsa-deploy.yml - include: cmc-deploy.yml - include: nova-deploy.yml - include: hooks.d/myservice/post-nova-deploy.yml - include: cinder-deploy.yml - include: octavia-deploy.yml - include: designate-deploy.yml ...
body.p: where the inclusion of hooks.d/myservice/post-nova-deploy.yml is after nova-deploy.yml Typically, these hook playbooks simply call out to other third-party playbooks, e.g.:
body.codeblock:
stack@hlm:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ cat hooks.d/myservice/post-nova-deploy.yml # # (c) Copyright 2017 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # Post nova-deploy logic goes here, can include anothe playbook.
- include: "{{ playbook_dir }}/myservice-deploy.yml"
body.p: The nett result is that the myservice deployment is carried out after nova has been deployed. Similarly, hlm-reconfigure.yml, hlm-upgrade.yml, hlm-start.yml and hlm-stop.yml are generated to contain any hooks, if they have been defined.

In deploying , customers may want to modify some of the configuration files supplied by . To facilitate this, the ~/helion/my_cloud/config area on the lifecycle manager contains a set of symlinks to configuration file templates for the various services in . To customise, the customer edits these files directly and commits to git (see Using GIT ) and those configuration changes will be persisted and used for all future deployments and upgrades.

If you have third-party configuration templates that you would like to expose for customer modification in the same way, you must create a symlinks yaml definition and place it in a config directory in your ansible area, e.g. config/myservice-symlinks.yaml as shown in the sample Ansible layout above. This yaml file is simply a list of paths to configuration templates to be mapped to the name that each will appear as in the ~/helion/my_cloud/config area. Configuration templates are typically grouped by service under ~/helion/my_cloud/config. A sample symlinks specification is as follows:
body.codeblock: # (c) Copyright 2017 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development LP # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # The following relative symlinks are created under the # my_cloud/config directory. --- symlinks: "myservice/server.conf.j2": "roles/myservice-server/templates/server.conf.j2"
body.p: When the above file is parsed by the third-party-import playbook, a ~/helion/my_cloud/myservice/server.conf.j2 symlink will be added to point to the configuration template under the myservice-server role.

p.ph: It is not uncommon for a third-party service integration to require additional content to be deployed to a node, where that content is not packaged as a deb/rpm or is a python application that could be deployed into a venv. Helion lifecycle manager provides a generic mechanism for packaging such content and delivering it to target nodes (coupled with the use of Helion lifecycle manager Ansible modules in the 3rd-party Ansible playbooks). For example, this mechanism can be used to deliver a Java-based application to target Cloud nodes. Helion lifecycle manager packages this content and makes it available in the same repo used for serving out python venvs, as shown in the diagram below:
To prepare such content to be packaged, you should follow these steps:

ol.li: Create an appropriately-named sub-directory under the other directory for each separate set of application content to be imported.
For each of these sub-directories, populate with the set of application content; this does not need to confirm to any particular layout.

body.p: A sample layout for other application content that is be imported is as follows:

When the third-party-import playbook has been completed, the above content is bundled into a single package and made available on the venv repo of the lifecycle manager node. An example playbook task for delivering this bundled package to a target cloud node is as follows:
body.codeblock: - name: serviceA-server | install | Install myserviceA package become: yes install_package: name: serviceA service: serviceA state: present activate: act_on register: serviceA_install_result

body.p: provides a centralised logging service, which collects log files for all services and stores them in a centralized elasticsearch store, where they can then be viewed, searched and analyzed via a Kibana interface. To configure a third-party service for this centralized logging service, you must add a logging profile yaml file under the logging directory, e.g.:

Note that in addition to configuring a service for centralized logging, the above profile also defines the logrotate policy for the service. For details on creating a logging profile and general info on the centralized logging service, please see the documentation here. .

p.ph: Some services provide an interface for injecting third-party customizations of the deployment of that service, which includes the addition of configuration data to certain selected configuration files. The specifics of what can be customized depends on the service. The general model is that a third-party service definition can declare that it provides data (provides-data relationship) to another service or service-component, where that data could be the name of one or more plugins/drivers, a chunk of additional configuration content or any other settings that exposed by the peer service/service-component. Currently, only the neutron service provides such an interface.

body.p: After deploying integrated with a third-party service, there are two main upgrade scenarios:

ol.li: upgrade (major, minor, patch or hotfix)
Upgrade of third-party content independent of a upgrade.

body.p: After deploying integrated with a third-party service, the following steps must be carried for any upgrade of (major, minor, patch, hotfix):

ol.li: Update the lifecycle manager: ~/hos-4.x.y/hos-init.bash

If required, update third-party content, e.g. contents under ~/third-party/myservice. If the third-party integration involves the patching of a venv and the upgrade involves a change in OpenStack release (e.g. Mitaka to Newton), then an update of the plugin code used to patch the venv may be required.

Run the 3rd-party import playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost third-party-import.yml If the third-party integration involves the patching of a Neutron venv (and Neutron has since changed in this upgrade), then the import playbook step will reapply that plugin to the latest Neutron venv supplied in the upgrade kit.

Proceed with a cloud upgrade as per normal:
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml -e encrypt="" -e rekey=""
Ready the deployment: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Upgrade the cloud. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-upgrade.yml

body.p: It is critical to re-run a third-party import after the hos-init step and before an upgrade is started. Omitting the import leaves you in danger of overwriting a previously patched and deployed venv with the latest one supplied in the upgrade kit. For this reason, hos-init.bash will display a warning message when it detects that third-party content has been previously supplied.
It is also possible to update third-party content independently of a upgrade, e.g. update the plugin used to patch the Neutron venv. To update third-party content, the following steps apply:

ol.li: Update the relevant third-party content under ~/third-party, e.g. ~/third-party/myservice

Run the 3rd-party import playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost third-party-import.yml If the third-party update involves the change of a Neutron plugin, the latest Neutron venv will be selected and patched with the latest third-party content. This is guaranteed to be selected over the previous patched venv in a subsequent upgrade.

Proceed with a cloud upgrade as per normal:
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml -e encrypt="" -e rekey=""
Ready the deployment: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Upgrade the cloud. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-upgrade.yml Note that the above steps includes running the config-processor and a ready-deployment step. While this is not specifically required for all types of third-party update (e.g. only changing a venv), it is safest to run the full set of steps to guarantee that all third-party changes are pulled into the next deployment/upgrade.
